metadata.title: Animal Parvoviruses: Comparative Aspects and Diagnosis

body_text.text: The smallest DNA-containing animal viruses, the Parvoviridae, have been discovered mainly during the last two decades. Some of these agents were related to a sometimes fatal disease, others were associated with adenoviruses, but most were at the time of discovery not etiologically related to a definite disease. Initial interest arose mainly with the discovery that these virions encapsidate a singlestranded DNA. This finding raised the question of how single-stranded DNA viruses are replicated in eukaryotic cells. More recently, however, parvoviruses have been associated with economically and hygienically important diseases.

For earlier reviews on various aspects of the parvoviruses, the reader is re ferred to Toolan (1968) (biological aspects of these viruses); Hoggan (1971) (physicochemical and comparative aspects); Rose (1974) (comprehensive review, with emphasis on adenovirus-associated viruses); (autonomously replicating vertebrate parvoviruses); Kurstak et al. (1977a) (insect parvoviruses); Kurstak and Tijssen (1977) (human parvoviruses); Andrewes et al. (1978) and Toolan and Ellem (1979) (overview of parvovirology, with emphasis on mor phogenesis and replication); (molecular biology of adenovirus-associated viruses).

In this chapter, we will deal first with the general physicochemical, biological, antigenic, and serological properties of the vertebrate animal parvoviruses. Sub sequently, we will discuss in more detail the infection and replication mecha nisms and the pathogenesis of these viruses. Finally, we will cover the aspects of diagnosis, epizootiology, prevention, and control.

By definition, the members of the parvovirus group contain single-stranded, linear DNA. So far, this feature is unique to this family. Moreover, the other morphological and physicochemical characteristics of the Parvoviridae are also similar and unique among all viruses.

These nonenveloped viral particles all possess a cubic symmetry (Fig. 1) , with this respect until now, however, all have overlapping genes. The single-stranded DNAs of these agents all seem to possess hairpin structures at both ends. The biological characteristics of these viruses are also very congruent. They multiply best in rapidly dividing cells, such as are found in embryonic, tumor or healing tissues. It was found that all parvoviruses depend on certain cellular or helper virus functions. These viruses are often latent or produce only subtle and transient cytopathic effects. Also interesting is the characteristic of their associa tion with the nucleolus during the replication.

Until recently, no clear pathogenic role of the parvoviruses was known except for the DNV 1 and FPV/MEV viruses. The discovery of these agents was mainly due to mere chance. Nevertheless, the great importance of this virus family, with the notorious exception of the various adeno-associated viruses (AAVs), is increasingly recognized. The clinical significance of the AAV group still remains to be established. This group may even be beneficial in that it inhibits the adenoviruses without causing a disease ("friendly viruses").

Most parvoviruses are able to agglutinate erythrocytes of various origins. This property, because of its simplicity, has been exploited extensively. Various immunological procedures have been used to differentiate these viruses, such as immunofluorescence, serum neutralization, complement fixation, immunodiffusion, and hemagglutination inhibition. Several serological relationships among the different parvo virus candidates have thus been described.

The LHT system of virus classification (see Lwoff and Tournier, 1971 ) uses four criteria: (1) nature of the genetic material; (2) symmetry of the capsid; (3) naked or enveloped nature of the nucleocapsid; (4) diameter of the nucleocapsid for the virions with helical symmetry or number of capsomers for the virions with cubic symmetry, the numerical data allowing for diversity.

The very small animal DNA viruses are similar with regard to these four characteristics and have, therefore, been grouped together as the family of the Parvoviridae (Lwoff and Tournier, 1971; Hoggan, 1971 ). This name was ap proved by the Executive Committee of the International Committee on Nomen clature of Viruses (Andrewes, 1970) , while the name "picodnavirus" (Mayor and Melnick, 1966) was not. Though the number of these agents has steadily increased, the homogeneity of the general properties was highly conserved, justifying amply their classification as a separate group.

Besides these four characteristics in common, there also exist striking differ ences among the various parvoviruses. A number of these viruses are not capable of autonomous reproduction and need a helper virus. For this reason, Melnick l The full names of the abbreviated virus names are given in Table 1 (pp. 7 and 8).

(1971) divided the parvoviruses into two major groups (genera): (1) nondefective and (2) defective parvoviruses. About this time, it also became evident why some parvoviruses appeared to contain double-stranded DNA. It was found that some parvoviruses encapsidate only one particular strand of the replicative form, whereas others encapsidate separately the complementary single strands. Upon extraction, these complementary strands may anneal spontaneously to form doublestranded DNA.
Currently, the Parvoviridae are, therefore, divided into three genera (Table I ) (Bachmann et al., 1979) :

1. Parvovirus. The members of this genus do not need a helper virus in their replication, and they encapsidate one specific strand of the DNA. Until now, these viruses have been isolated only from vertebrate hosts.

2. Adenovirus-associated virus (or Adenosatellovirus). The viruses of this genus replicate only with the aid of a helper virus. They encapsidate separately both strands of the replicative form. These viruses are not found in organisms other than vertebrates.
3. Densovirus. These viruses replicate autonomously and encapsidate both DNA strands separately. They have been isolated only from invertebrates.

Though this classification suffers from the drawback that other parameters have been chosen to distinguish, for instance, the Adenosatellovirus from the Parvovirus than for the separation of the Densovirus from the Adenosatellovirus, it is convenient for the time being. The inclusion of 0X174 in the Parvoviridae (Salzman, 1978) is not justified. This bacteriophage differs in the structure of its DNA (circular, single-stranded) and protein makeup. However, virus associated with Aleutian mink disease may belong to the Parvoviridae.

In Table I a more detailed classification of the parvoviruses is given. The Densovirus genus will not be dealt with in detail in this chapter, since it is the subject of a chapter in a future volume of these series, though it is sometimes discussed for comparative reasons.

Infections by parvoviruses often cause the formation of basophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies (Fig. 2) (Dawe et al., 1961; Ferm and Kilham, 1964; Studdert and Peterson, 1973) similar to that of most DNA viruses. Moreover, the repro duction is inhibited by agents which block DNA synthesis. These biological observations provide evidence that parvoviruses contain a DNA genome (Payne et al., 1963; Mayr et al., 1968) . Direct chemical analysis of purified virus confirmed this and revealed a DNA content of 20-30% (Cheong et al., 1965 ; P a r k s t .

Some early studies seemed to indicate a double-stranded nature of the DNA (Hampton, 1964; Whally, 1965; Johnson and Cruickshank, 1966; May et al., 1967) , although acridine orange staining Mayor and Jordan, 1966) suggested the DNA of the autonomous parvoviruses to be of a single-stranded configuration. Also, the nucleic acid in the complete virions readily reacted with formaldehyde (resulting in about 20% hyperchromicity), indicating a single-stranded structure (Crawford, 1966) . These findings were confirmed by physicochemical studies on the extracted nucleic acid (Table II) , with the following results: (1) the buoyant density of the DNA was not affected by alkali denaturation and neutralization; (2) no definite melting point of the isolated nucleic acids could be found during thermal denaturation (under neutral conditions).

The first results with AAV were far less clear. Staining reactions and treatment with formaldehyde indicated a single-stranded structure (Mayor and Melnick, 1966; Mayor et al., 1969) . However, physiocochemical examinations of the extracted DNA showed that the AAV DNA was double-stranded (Rose et al., 1966 (Rose et al., , 1968 Parks et al., 1967) . Crawford et al. (1969) found a close similarity between these physicochemical properties of the virions of the defective viruses and those of the autonomous viruses, and they speculated that the single-stranded complementary strands of DNA were separately encapsidated. This hypothesis was found to be correct (Rose et al., 1969; Mayor et al., 1969) . Similar produc tion, segregation and encapsidation of the viral DNA were also observed for the densonucleosis viruses (Kurstak, 1972; Mayor and Kurstak, 1974; Kurstak et. al., 1977a) .

There is a considerable similarity among the base composition values for MVM, H-l, and KRV DNA, but their composition is clearly different from that of AAV-2 DNA. The molecular weights of the various parvo virus genomes center on 1.5 X 10 6 daltons (Table II) .

All parvoviruses thus far examined in this respect have hairpin duplexes at both ends of their genomes. AAV DNA contains both natural and inverted terminal nucleotide sequences, consistent with a palindromic sequence arrange ment at both genome termini Berns and Kelly, 1974) . These terminal repetitions are about 150 nucleotides long. The DNAs of the autonomous parvoviruses, however, do not have an inverted terminal repetition (Bourguignon et al., 1976) . Moreover, the 3' and 5' ends of the AAV genomes are complementary, whereas the two ends of the autonomous genomes differ in size and sequence and are not complementary (Astell et al., 1979) . Astell et al. (1979) characterized the 3' termini of the DNA from four autono mous rodent parvoviruses (KRV, MVM, . They demonstrated that these termini exist as Y-shaped hairpin structures involving 115 or 116 nucleo tides. The DNA sequence of this region is highly conserved among these four rodent parvoviruses, although there are some minor differences. Since these DNAs are readily distinguished on the basis of restriction enzyme maps, these 3' terminal homologies suggest either a pressure to conserve the sequence of the terminal hairpin structure or a close evolutionary relationship among these viruses.

Though the AAV-2 genome is topologically very similar to these autonomous parvovirus genomes, the hairpin of the genome of this defective parvovirus exhibits no sequence homology with them . In addition, the 3' termini of autonomous bovine (BPV) and human (LU III) parvoviruses pos- Johnson et al. (1974); B: McGeoch et al. (1970) ; C: Crawford et al. (1969) ; D: Bourguignon et al. ( , 1969 ; Rose and Koczot (1971) ; Koczot et al. (1973) ; Rose (1974) ; M: Truffaut et al. (1967) ; Longworth étal. (1968) ; Barwise and Walker (1970); Kmstaketal. (1971); Tijsseneia/. 12 Edouard Kurstak and Peter Tijssen sess a similar hairpin structure, whereas the nucleotide sequences are quite different from those of the rodent viruses or AAV (Astell et al., 1979) . The termini nucleotides of the AAV genome may occur in both normal and reverse orientations (that is, the terminal 100-150 nucleotides may be "flipflopped")· The observation by Astell et al. (1979) that the nucleotide sequence of the autonomous parvoviruses exists in a single orientation suggests that defec tive parvoviruses (and probably the densonucleosis viruses) replicate and mature by a mechanism different from that of the autonomous parvoviruses. Rose et al. (1968) assessed nucleic acid homologies among genomes from the four human and simian AAV serotypes. They demonstrated, employing synthetic RNA, that the interserotypic homologies ranged from 27 to 37%.

Purified virions of parvoviruses are easily disrupted in a neutral solution containing 1% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and 1% 2-mercaptoethanol. The different denatured components of the capsids can be separated by SDS polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The molecular weights and the stoichiometry of the structural proteins of the various parvoviruses, estimated by the method of Weber and Osborn (1969) , are remarkably similar (Tables III, IV) .

About 2-4 different proteins are found for each virus, with molecular weights between 50,000 and 100,000. The major protein component comprises about 70 to 80% of the capsid. Since the particle weight and the percentage of protein mass per virion are also known, it is possible to estimate the number of mole cules of each protein per virion. The major protein of all parovoviruses studied in this respect seems to be present in about 60 copies per virion. This finding suggests that the capsid structure of these parvoviruses will also be very similar, unlike the wide variation of the results obtained from electron microscopic ob servations.

The differences in the molecular weights reported may be smaller 1 than appar ent from Tables III and IV; for example, compare the two studies in Table III on MVM proteins. Usually these differences among the various parvoviruses are significantly reduced if electrophoresed together J. Kongsvik, personal communication) .

ref_spans.text: Tables III and IV; for example, compare the two studies in Table III

body_text.text: The origin of some proteins with a relatively low molecular weight (e.g., in FPV/MEV, H-l, and MVM preparations) is as yet not firmly established. A study on DNV (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1981) indicated that lower-molecularweight proteins may arise by proteolytic cleavage of the viral peptides in the virus preparations rather than by contamination with nonviral peptides. A third protein, sometimes present in Lu III preparations, with a molecular weight between those of the two viral peptides, seems to be of cellular origin (Gautschi et al., 1976) .

Though DNA polymerase activity was reported to be associated with KRV Johnson et al. (1974) ; B: Kongsvik and Toolan (1972b) ; C: Salzman and White (1970) ; D: Clinton and Hayashi (1975) ; E: Tattersall et al. (1976) ; F: Johnson and Hoggan (1973) ; G: Salo and Mayor (1977) ; H: Gautschi and Siegl (1973) ; I: Bloom et al. (1980) . particles (Salzman, 1971; Salzman and McKerlie, 1975) , attempts to demon strate the association of such enzymatic activities with other parvoviruses failed (Rhode, 1973) . No other enzymatic activities have as yet been reported for the parvoviral proteins. It seems, however, that they play an essential role in the replication and maturation of the virus (see Section VI). The parvovirus genomes, in general, do not contain the coding capacity for the combined molecular weights of their structural proteins. This might be explained by the presence of overlapping genes in the viral DNA or by an incorporation of host proteins. Similarities among the structural proteins have been shown by peptide mapping for MVM (Tattersall et al., 1977) and DNV (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979b) . These experiments revealed that for a given parvovirus all structural proteins have common sequences. Pulse-chase experiments seem to indicate that the AAV proteins also have an important overlap of the primary structure Buller and Rose, 1978; Salo and Mayor, 1978) . However, these authors disagree on whether a precursor protein exists or whether mecha nisms other than posttranslational proteolytic processing are involved (e.g., AAV polypeptides generated at the level of protein synthesis).

The infectious agent of Aleutian disease, a virus-induced immune complex disease of mink, is most recently considered to be a member of the parvovirus group (Chesebro et al., 1975; Chó, 1976; Hahn et al., 1977; Shahrabadi et al, 1977) . However, the protein composition of this virus (ADV) appears to be different from that of the parvoviruses. Polypeptide analysis of ADV by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis revealed four polypeptides with molecular weights of 30,000, 27,000, 20,500, and 14,000. Stoichiometrically, these polypeptides were present in a ratio of 10:3:10:1, respectively (Shahrabadi et al., 1977) . These data indicate that ADV is not closely related to the parvoviruses. Howev er, Bloom et al. (1980) presented evidence that ADV contains two structural proteins. The number of these polypeptides (and their molecular weights of 89,000 and 77,600) is very similar to that of the other parvoviruses of the Parvovirus genus. These investigators also observed, after prolonged exposure, other faint bands of peptides with lower molecular weights.

Two fundamentally different capsid structure formations and virus maturation mechanisms are beginning to be distinguished among the parvoviruses. These specific differences divide the parvoviruses into two groups: (1) the Parvovirus and (2) the Adenosatellovirus and Densovirus. All the members of the Parvovirus group seem initially to contain two structural proteins (Table III) . The major protein may be cleaved during a maturation process so that a third protein with a slightly lower molecular weight appears and the formerly noninfectious particle becomes infectious (Tattersall et al., , 1977 . The buoyant density of the MVM virions also decreases during this cleavage (or maturation) process . (Clin ton and Hayashi, 1975) , which probably is general for the Parvovirus genus. The members of the other genera in the Parvoviridae also have particles (with complete DNA) of two different densities. The differences between these two particles reside in the relative quantity of the two intermediate-weight proteins (Table IV) and a different quaternary structure . However, virions of both densities are infectious, in contrast to the Parvovirus genus, as described above.
All structural proteins have an external orientation (see Section IV, C).

The finding by electron microscopy or ultrafiltration that a certain virus is small is often the first indication that the agent is a potential member of the parvoviridae family. The parvoviruses are the smallest (20-24 nm) among the animal viruses. Although these viruses possess a cubic symmetry, the definition of the fine structure has proved difficult to resolve because of their small size and their very tight, close-packed capsids.
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: The variation in size and structure reported by different workers is consider able (Table V) . This contrasts to the close similarities of the biochemical and biophysical data obtained for the different parvoviruses and their constituents. These similarities suggest strongly that the structure of the parvoviruses does not vary as widely as studies on the morphology or their interpretation seem to indicate.
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: The variation in size measurements can be accounted for in a number of ways. The first factor to be considered is the well-known fact that the stain used and the method of application may affect the apparent size. Hoggan (1971) showed that when 1% uranyl acetate is used on RV, H-l, HADEN (= BPV-1), DNV, MVM, or the AAV serotypes, they appear 12 to 15% larger than when replicate preparations are stained with 2% PTA. There may also be varying degrees of flattening of the particles on the grid. Moreover, the virus particles are not truly spherical, making it difficult to determine a definitive size for them. In the measurement of an icosahedron, the diameter varies in accordance with the direction of viewing, as Karasaki (1966) has noted. In an icosahedral model, the relative lengths of the maximum and minimum diameters are 1.00 and 0.85, respectively. Therefore, Karasaki (1966) preferred the measurement of a diame ter drawn from side to side, rather than vertex to vertex of the profiles of 4 'complete" particles viewed along a three-or fivefold axis, since the side-to-side distances in both symmetry profiles are the same: the relative lengths are 0.85. Magnification errors of the microscopes might add some supplementary differ ences. In fact, diameters of various parvoviruses are rather similar if measured in the same study.
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: Thus the choice of stain and the way of measuring may account for a differ ence of 30%, or about 6 nm of the different diameters. Calculations show that electron microscopic studies indicating a difference of only 26% in diameter suggest the larger particle (if the buoyant densities are the same) to have twice Cho and Ingram (1974) Kurstak and Côté (1969) Kurstak (1979a) Hoggan (1965) Archetti and Bocciarelli (1965) Smith et al. (1966 ) Hoggan (1971 Mayor er al. (1965 ) Hoggan (1971 ) Dutta(1975 ) Luchsinger et al. (1970 ) Yates et al. (1973 ) Clarke et al. (1979 the weight of the smaller particle. These reported size variations are more appar ent than real since the particle weights and buoyant densities of the various viruses are, as we will see in Section IV D, quite similar.
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: Calculations from the known densities and molecular weights of the particles, assuming a dodecahedral structure of the virions, suggest a diameter of 24 nm (vertex to vertex) or 22.5 nm (side to side) in the fivefold position (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979a) .
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: The two reports on protein localization in the virions indicate that all three major proteins have external orientations (Lübeck and Johnson, 1977; Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979a) . Studies in our laboratory suggest that five molecules of the major protein cluster into a ring-like structure: the capsomer. Twelve capsomers are assembled into a complete particle. Therefore, the particle is a dodecahedron rather than an icosahedron (Fig. 3) . The proteins intermediate in quantity and molecular weight seem to attach to the center of the ring-like capsomers, giving Morphology of densonucleosis virus. The dodecahedron seems best to fit the structure of DNV (-►). In dodecahedral structures the number of vertices is 20 instead of 12 and the number of faces 12 instead of 20 when compared to an icosahedron. The ring-like molecules fit the size and structure of regular pentagons of such dodecahedrons and probably represent the capsomers (pentamers) . Bar represents 50 nm. the latter a "full" aspect. These various structures can be seen by electron microscopy since the buoyant density (1.31 gm/ml) of the hydrated protein and the molecular weights are known; the size of the ring-like capsomer (a pentamer) can easily be calculated, assuming a globular structure for each protein. The minimum diameter of the major structural protein of the parvoviruses is then about 5 nm and that of the capsomer about 10 nm. Such capsomer-like struc tures, compatible in size with these calculations, have been observed in a number of studies (Table V) .
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: Other reports (Table V) (Bachmann et al., 1979) , stating that the diameter of the capsomers measures 3 nm, are not compatible with the biochemical data. A globular protein with a diameter of 3 nm has a molecular weight of about 11,000. The smallest viral structural protein already has a molecular weight of about 50,000 (Section IV B). For the same reason, 32, the most frequently reported number of capsomers, is too high to cover a capsid of this size.
body_text.section: C. Structure and Size of Viral Particles

body_text.text: The high DNA/protein ratio and the tight capsids (less water in the virion) of the parvoviruses result in a relatively high buoyant density in a CsCl solution. The reported buoyant densities for the same virus sometimes show significant differences (Table VI) . These differences are probably attributable not only to the method and precision of measurement in the different laboratories but also to the often observed heterogeneity of the virus preparation. In general, the high den sity is a valuable property for the purification and classification of the viruses.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: The empty capsids band at 1.30 to 1.32 gm/ml in CsCl gradients (Payne et al., 1964; Jamison and Mayor, 1965; Greene and Karasaki, 1965; Whally, 1965; Crawford, 1966) . The infectious particles band at about 1.40 gm/ml (ElDadahef al., 1967; Mayr et al.,\96S; Robinson and Hetrick, 1969; McGtoch et al., 1970; Studdert and Peterson, 1973) . There is often a supplementary band at about 1.45 gm/ml (May and May, 1970; Johnson et al., 1974; . The virus in this band is not distinguishable from the 1.40 gm/ml particles in hemagglutination ability or DNA structure.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: There is often an intermediate band (1.34-1.37 gm/ml) containing particles with very low infectivity (Robinson and Hetrick, 1969; May and May, 1970; Bachmann, 1971; Johnson and Hoggan, 1973; Johnson et al., 1974) . These particles contain DNA which is considerably smaller than the genome size. The low infectivity of this virus band may be due to the presence of complete particles in the form of aggregates with incomplete particles.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: It is evident from the above that it is not possible to distinguish parvoviruses according to their buoyancy behavior.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: The reason for the presence of two infectious virus bands has not been defi-nitely established. We have already mentioned (Section IV, B) that the heavy band contains virions whose capsids have a different quaternary structure and lack some protein molecules . Purified particles of either band will produce particles of both densities during the infection cycle. Clinton and Hayashi (1975) demonstrated that immature MVM bands at a higher density than the mature virus. This also gives two different particles, but this phenome non is quite different from the situation described above, in which the mature particles shed about 10 protein molecules and hence become denser and (as we will see later) have a lower sedimentation coefficient. Clinton and Hayashi (1975) also noted that after maturation and its concurrent lowering of the density, the virions may undergo another structural change so that they band again at a higher density (by shedding some of the proteins?).
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: In most of the density gradient experiments, a 40% CsCl solution is used and the centrifugation is done at 40,000 rpm for 20 hours at 20°C. Potassium tartrate has also been used with success with RV. This virus then banded at 1.31-1.32 gm/ml, probably due to a different solvation of the particles in the presence of this salt (Breese^c//., 1964; Whitman and Hetrick, 1967) .
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: The variations in the reported sedimentation coefficients (S) of the various parvoviruses (Table VI ) may reflect differences in experimental conditions rather than significant differences in values. Measurements in the same laboratory often lead to a much narrower range of values; for example, McGeoch et al. (1970) observed that the S values of MVM, RV, and H-l were all 110 ± 2 S. The presence of both infectious types in the test may contribute to a possible experi mental inaccuracy. We found in our laboratory that the infectious particles in the band of the highest density also have the lowest S value. In general, empty capsids have a sedimentation rate of about 60 S.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: Absorption spectra in the ultraviolet region of these viruses have a maximum at about 260 nm and a minimum of 240 nm, with absorbance ratios of 260/280 nm and 260/240 nm over 1.5 for the purified virus . Absorbance of these particles also allows an estimation of their concentration since their extinction coefficients A 260 nm· l cm a r e a b°u t 6.5-9.0 cm 2 /mg. The light scattering is mostly very small for this size and type of particles, making a correction unnecessary if the pH of the buffer is sufficiently different from the isoelectric point (pi) of the virus and the ionic strength is not too low.
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: Few reports deal with pis of these viruses. Mayor et al. (1977) showed X14 and AAV viruses to have a very low pi (2.5-3.0). In contrast, for DNV a heterogeneous virus population was observed from pi 5.7 to 6.5 (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979a) . This may be the reason why DNV, in contrast to many other parvoviruses, can be found in paracrystalline formations in the nucleus (Garzon and Kurstak, 1976) . Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of the complete particles produced a single-migrating band for both the 1.40 gm/ml and the 1.44 gm/ml types of infectious virions . (1970)
body_text.section: D. Physicochemical Properties of the Virions

body_text.text: Parvoviruses have a strong resistance to heating. In general, they do not lose infectivity during incubation at 56°C for 30 minutes (Abinanti and Warfield, 1961; Mayr et al., 1968) , but prolonged heating at 80°C decreases the infective titer significantly (Lum and Schreiner, 1963; Greene, 1965; Brailovsky, 1966; Johnson and Cruickshank, 1966; Cartwright^a/., 1969) . The pH of the medium may influence the stability of the virus during the heating experiments (Siegl et al., 1971) , a pH around neutrality being the most favorable for stability.
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: Parvoviruses usually retain their infectivity during incubation in a wide pH range (pH 3-10). However, purified viruses have a significantly lower stability than does the virus in crude extracts (Siegl et al., 1971; Tijssen et al., 1977) .
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: The high stability of the virus is also reflected by its ability to survive storage. Parvoviruses lose very little infectivity when stored in suspension, especially if they are frozen and not purified (Toolan, 1968; Cartwright et al., 1969; Rose, 1974) . Resistance of the purified virus to lyophilization is weak (Lum and Schreiner, 1963) ; lyophilized tissue culture harvests were reported to retain their infectivity (Seigl, 1976 ). An equal volume of glycerol is often added to the virus suspension to provide additional stability during storage. Also, Siegl et al. (1971) observed that Tris buffer (pH 7.6) is preferred to phosphate buffered saline (pH 7.4) as a storage medium.
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: The lack of an envelope indicates why the infectivity and hemagglutination characteristics of these viruses are not affected by treatments with organic sol vents such as butanol, chloroform, ether, and carbon tetrachloride (Cartwright and Huck, 1967) . These viruses are, however, rapidly dissociated in SDS.
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: The resistance of parvoviruses to various enzymes such as nucleases (RNase, DNase) and proteases (papain, chymotrypsin, trypsin, pepsin) enables the use of these enzymes to eliminate cellular nucleic acids and proteins during virus purifi cation (May and May, 1970; Kongsvik and Toolan, 1972a) . Sometimes a trypsin treatment may even increase the infectivity titer (Mayr et al., 1968) .
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: Parvoviruses are quite resistant to ultrasonication. This treatment may there fore be used successfully to purify these viruses from infected cells (Breese et al., 1964; Vasquez and Brailovsky, 1965; Brailovsky, 1966) .
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: Ultraviolet light inactivates parvoviruses readily (Kilham and Olivier, 1959; Toolan, 1960) . Inactivation of these viruses is also efficient by treatment with formaline (Johnson, 1969) . Therefore, formaline-inactivated virus proved to be an effective vaccine in the early days (Urbain, 1933) .
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: Finally, care should be taken in the radioactive labeling of the nucleic acid of these viruses. Because of its single-stranded nature, parvoviral DNA is frag mented about 10 times more efficiently by radioactive decay than are doublestranded genomes of similar radioactivity.
body_text.section: E. Resistance of Parvo viruses to Physical and Chemical Agents

body_text.text: The ease and speed of the hemagglutination method favor its use in the characterization of viruses with a varying ability to agglutinate different erythrocytes.

Until now, parvoviruses encapsidating only one specific DNA strand (the Parvovirus genus), with the exception of DDV, were all shown to agglutinate erythrocytes of at least one animal species, whereas viruses encapsidating sepa rately the complementary DNA strands often lack this ability. Particular parvo viruses can be distinguished, especially on a preliminary basis, by their specific hemagglutination pattern under standardized conditions (Table VII) . Human, guinea pig, rat, and pig erythrocytes are the primary species of interest for the parvovirologist. In contrast, bovine red blood cells have not yet been shown to be agglutinated by any parvovirus, whereas those from rabbits gave only a weak reaction with H-3 and X14. Erythrocytes of other species of mammalian and avian origin are, however, often needed to distinguish the various parvoviruses. Only a few parvoviruses (KBSH/PPV, H-l, RTV, and some latent parvoviruses isolated from established cell lines) agglutinate avian erythrocytes, whereas oth ers (e.g., MVM, MVC, FPV) have a rather limited agglutination range. FPV/MEV agglutinates only pig erythrocytes, whereas MVC was shown to agglutinate only rhesus or African green monkey erythrocytes. In this respect, the hemagglu tination pattern of the recently discovered canine enteritis virus is of interest. This virus shows many similarities with the FPV/MEV group. The hemaggluti nation results (Table VII) could, in fact, indicate a relationship with either FPV or MVC.

Some parvoviruses, such as the rodent viruses, agglutinate erythrocytes at 4°C as well as at 37°C (Toolan, 1968) , but for a large number of viruses such as RPV, MEV, FPV, and AAV-4, hemagglutination occurs only at 4°C and sometimes only after ultrasonication of the virus samples (Johnson and Cruickshank, 1966; Ito and Mayor, 1968; Luchsingeref a/., 1970; Matsunagae/a/., 1977) . At 37°C, and sometimes also at room temperature, these viruses seem to be eluted from the red blood cells without destroying their receptor sites since the reaction is reversible (Ito and Mayor; Luchsinger et al., 1970) . BPV, PPV, and ovine AAV are capable of hemagglutination at higher temperatures, but the most consistent results were obtained at 4°C (Mayr et al., 1968; Bachmann, 1971; Clarke et al. y 1979) . Variations in the pH may also influence the hemagglutinating ability, and virus can be eluted within half an hour from the erythrocytes at pH 9 without destruction of the receptor sites.
We have already seen that the hemagglutinating antigen is a protein devoid of ON

Monkey Table I . b x, positive reaction; o, no reaction; o/x, conflicting results. c A: Hallauer et al. (1971) ; B: Hoggan (1971) ; C: Abinanti and Warfield (1961) ; Bachmann (1971) ; D: Bates et al. (1972) ; F: Inaba et al. (1973) ; G: Johnson and Cruickshank (1966) ; H: Binn et al. (1970) ; I: Toolan (1967) ; J: Kilham and Olivier (1959) ; K: Clarke et al. (1979) ; L: Ito and Mayor (1968) ; M: Hoggan (1970) ; N: Crawford (1966) ; P: Matsunaga et al. (1977) ; Q: lipids and sugars. On the whole, the chemical properties of the parvo virus agglutinins appear to be different from those of other hemagglutinating viruses; nevertheless, there are some similarities with the agglutinins of entero-and adenoviruses, such as the sensitivity to p-chloromercuribenzoate (Castro et al., 1971) . Proteins isolated from AAV-4, X14, and BPV, after dissociation of the virions by SDS, lost their hemagglutinating activity (Johnson and Hoggan, 1973; Salo and Mayor, 1977) . Small particles (± 10 nm in diameter) which can be isolated from X14 preparations have a hemagglutinating activity but are not infectious (Breese et al., 1964) . Though such small particles have been found associated with other parvoviruses (Section IV, C) and most probably represent capsomers (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979a) , information on whether they have the same hemagglutinating abilities as the complete virions is still lacking. On the other hand, this does not mean that at least subassembled particles are needed for hemagglutination, since the treatment of the virus by SDS not only dissociates but also denatures the proteins. This denaturation alone could prevent hemagglu tination.

The investigations of Cocuzza and Russo (1969) suggest that the erythrocyte receptor site is a glycolipid containing N-acetyl-neuraminic acid linked with carbohydrates and fatty acids. Pretreatment of the red blood cells with neuraminidase (RDE) or with viruses containing this enzyme prevents the subsequent hemagglutination by parvoviruses (Hallauer and Kronauer, 1962; Hallauer et al., 1972) .

There is no reason why hemagglutination ability should be linked directly to infectivity, since the integrity of the hemagglutinating antigens varies indepen dently of the capability of the viral genome to infect a cell. Hence, "empty" capsids cannot be distinguished from "full" capsids on the basis of hemaggluti nation results.

Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) with antisera allows the establishment of an antigenic relationship among a certain set of viruses. Often nonspecific inhibi tions are present in normal sera or in antisera (Hallauer et al., 1972) . These inhibitors may be removed with kaolin by the method of Clarke and Casals (1958) . Illustrative of such an interference is the strong inhibitor isolated from human placentas for H-1 agglutinin, whereas, interestingly, RV and H-3 aggluti nins are not inhibited at all (Toolan, 1964; Usategui-Gomez and Morgan, 1968 ). Nevertheless, if homologous and heterologous antisera are available, HI by antisera is a convenient method to establish antigenic relationships. A reciprocal antigenic relationship was observed between H-1 and HT, between PPV and KBSH, and among RV, H-3, and X14; hemagglutination by other viruses tested (RTV, HB, MVM, FPV/MEV, BPV, MVC, Lu III, and TVX) was not or was to a very small extent inhibited by heterologous antisera . Joo et al. (1976b) investigated several variables for PPV HI tests. They adsorbed the antisera first with 25% in borate saline at pH 9. Natural hemagglutinins in test sera could be completely removed using 0.1 ml of packed erythrocytes to 0.6 ml of kaolin-treated sera. The highest virus-specific HI titers were obtained using guinea pig blood cells after an incubation of the virus with the serum for 18 hours at 4°C, 3 hours at 25°C, or 2 hours at 37°C.

Early attempts to detect hemadsorption on parvovirus-infected cells failed (Kilham and Olivier, 1959; Hallauer and Kronauer, 1962) . Subsequent studies by Portella (1964) did not confirm these findings. He demonstrated simultaneous hemagglutination abilities toward guinea pig, human, and rat erythrocytes during the course of RV reproduction in rat embryo tissue culture and showed that this agglutination ability is preceded by phenomena of hemadsorption when the washed sheets are exposed to erythrocyte suspensions. Portella (1964) observed that the supernatant fluids of H-l-and H-3-infected rat embryo tissue cultures hemagglutinate three types of erythrocytes, with the guinea pig cells consistently aggluti nating first. A few days later, H-l virus agglutinates human erythrocytes and H-3 hemagglutinates those of rats. Later, cells infected with either H-l or H-3 agglu tinate all three types of erythrocytes. Portella (1964) also showed by electron microscopy that the cells to which the erythrocytes adhered were infected. This phenomenon would thus facilitate the selection of suitable areas in the tissue culture for electron microscopic studies. Titers increased quickly after 10 days and showed a tendency to decrease after 30 days. Cartwright£/ al. (1969) observed, though not consistently, hemadsorption of chicken erythrocytes with PPV-infected pig kidney cells.

In agreement with Portella (1964) , Hallauer et al. (1972) also observed hemad sorption in KBSH-or RTV-infected cells; yet, in contrast to Portella, it occurred only at a stage of infection when the supernatant fluids had reached a rather high hemagglutination titer (1:1024) and a clear-cut cytopathic effect (CPE) could be seen. Moreover, the hemadsorption reaction was rather weak and confined to some singular cells which could be detected only by a careful microscopic examination of a more or less extended area of a cellular monolayer.
Because of these discrepancies, hemadsorption seems, at best, suitable to a limited number of viruses.

Serum neutralization (SN) is a powerful method used to assess antigenic relationships. The efficiency with which a certain antiserum to virus A reduces the infectivity of either virus A or virus B indicates the relatedness of those two viruses. Dalldorf noted in 1961 that H-3 and RV cross neutralize each other, while H-l was neutralized only by H-l antiserum (Toolan, 1968) . Later, Toolan (1964) observed that HT and H-l antisera are equally efficient in reducing the infectivity of either agent but not of other agents. HB also proved to be unrelated to the other rodent viruses. Other viruses whose homologous antisera interfere with the infectivity of H-3 and RV include the LS, X14, Kirk, and HER agents (Lum and Schreiner, 1963; Payne et al., 1964; ElDadah et al., 1967) . The homologous immune sera possess, however, a considerably higher SN titer than do the heterologous sera (Moore, 1962; Lum and Schreiner, 1963; Portella, 1964) . No relationships of these rodent osteolytic viruses could be demonstrated with the various AAV types (Hoggan, 1971) .

Although MVM does not cross-react by SN or HI with H-l or RV, it does cross-react in the fluorescent antibody tests (Cross and Parker, 1972) . Hoggan (1971) found that high-titered sera against BPV-1 (HADEN) did not neutralize RV, H-l, MVM, DNV, or the four AAV types. BPV-2, isolated by Inaba et al. (1973) in Japan, shares at most a minor antigenic component with BPV-1.

FPV, MEV, and feline ataxia virus appear closely related to each other by SN since they can be neutralized to almost the same degree by both homologous and heterologous antisera (Burger et al., 1963; Gorham et al., 1966; Johnson et al., 1967) . A later study revealed that FPV is morphologically and antigenically indistinguishable from mink enteritis virus (Johnson et al., 1974) . No serological relationship of these viruses with H-l or RV could be shown (Johnson et al., 1967) , but it would be of interest to compare the FPV/FLV/MEV with the canine enteritis virus.
The SN test revealed a serological relationship between AAV-2 and AAV-3, but not among AAV-1, AAV-4, and either AAV-2 or AAV-3 (Hoggan, 1971) .

Finally, plaque neutralization tests (see also section VII E) (Siegl and Kronauer, 1980) offer an effective means for studying such phenomena as maternally transmitted immunity, serological relationships, or nonspecific inhibitions.

The cytocidal potential of complement, occurring in vivo after reaction of erythrocytes with their antibodies, can be prevented by fixing the complement to other antigen-antibody complexes. This principle of complement fixation (CF) by parvoviral immune complexes has been used extensively in this field, though the technique is less sensitive and less specific than SN.

CF analyses of RV, H-l, and MVM were in agreement with the results ob tained with the SN test (Cross and Parker, 1972) in showing that these three viruses have distinct antigenicities. This confirmed the results obtained by using CF (Hoggan, 1971) . Moreover, Hoggan demonstrated that among AAV-1, AAV-2, AAV-3, AAV-4, RV, H-l, MVM, BPV-1, and DNV, a CF cross reac tivity exists only between AAV-2 and AAV-3, with significantly higher titers for the homologous antisera.

These techniques have been used in studies in the replication of parvoviruses and also for diagnostic and comparative purposes. The reader is referred to Kurstak^r al. (1977b) for a detailed description of these techniques.

CF, HI, and SN tests demonstrated an absence of antigenic relationships among RV, H-l, and MVM (see above sections). However, in conjunction with these tests, Cross and Parker (1972) also conducted fluorescence tests, and in contrast to the other tests, the latter suggested the presence of a common antigen. It should be borne in mind that in the immunofluorescence and immunoperoxidase tests, the antisera are tested on infected cells and not, as with the other tech niques, with purified virus. Pulse-chase experiments with infected cells did not reveal the presence of nonstructural proteins, and therefore the antigen in com mon was suspected to be a host cell protein. This protein could have been present in the cell-free but otherwise unpurified tissue culture harvests of these viruses. However, the recent discovery of a covalent association of a protein with replica tive DNA of parvovirus H-l (Revie et al., 1979) offers other possible explana tions. This protein, which is not found in mature H-l virions, could have the same antigenic determinants as similar proteins (if present) of other parvoviruses. Therefore, there might be a viral replication-related protein of parvoviruses, hitherto considered unrelated. The finding of Astell et al. (1979) that the nucleotide sequences of the 3' termini of the DNA from these rodent parvoviruses are quite similar for at least the first 115 nucleotides implies a closer relationship between these viruses than was expected by the serological methods. Hoggan (1971) also demonstrated an immuno-fluorescence cross-reaction between RV and H-l, in contrast to the results with SN. On the other hand, among the various AAV serotypes, he could show an immunofluorescence cross reaction only be tween AAV-2 and AAV-3, despite DNA homology studies demonstrating a 27-37% genome relatedness of these AAVs (Rosela/., 1968).
Other techniques used for the establishment of serological relationships among parvoviruses include (1) immunodiffusion and (2) microagglutination as seen in the electron microscope.
body_text.section: F. Other Serological Methods of Characterization

body_text.text: Immunodiffusion has the drawback that concentrated, purified antigen prepa rations are required. In our experience, the best results in the Ouchterlony doublediffusion technique are obtained at a virus concentration of about 0.1 optical density unit (at 260 nm, 1 cm pathway) per ml. Though Atchison et al. (1966) successfully employed this method for studying the distribution of antibodies, in general the use of this technique has been rather limited. Antiserum: AAAV AAV-1 AAV-2 AAV-3 AAV-4 Antiserum: H-l HT HB H-3 RV
body_text.section: F. Other Serological Methods of Characterization

body_text.text: a Symbols: x, aggregation of virus; -, no aggregation of virus. b Yates et al. (1973) . 1 Karasaki (1966) .
body_text.section: F. Other Serological Methods of Characterization

body_text.text: Though microagglutination [or immune electron microscopy (IEM)] necessi tates the use of an electron microscope, this technique is rather simple and economical. Negative staining of virus without prior treatment with specific antivirus antiserum may often result in a very sparse distribution of virus par ticles; also, different parvoviruses are virtually indistinguishable by electron microscopy. Virus suspensions treated with specific antiglobulin result in the formation of virus-antibody complexes which adhere to the grid and can readily be recognized in the electron microscope, even at low magnification (Karasaki, 1966) . The aggregates have a strong tendency to stick to the surface of the supporting film so that cellular debris is easily eliminated by subsequent washings. Karasaki (1966) observed that a low antibody concentration (e.g., 1:640) pro vided optimal conditions and that with this technique even capsid architecture could be studied. Yates et al. (1973) obtained an efficient aggregation using concentrated antiserum solutions (1:2 or 1:10), but the fibrous material (anti body) around the virions obscured their fine structure. This technique has been proven useful and very convenient in a number of cases (Table VIII) .
body_text.section: F. Other Serological Methods of Characterization

body_text.text: The parvoviruses have been classified according to their morphological and physicochemical properties into three genera (see Section III). However, if the replication alone is taken into account, only two different mechanisms emerge.

The first group, the so-called nondefective or autonomous parvoviruses, require replicating cells for their reproduction. Moreover, the 3' and 5' ends of the genome, which are peculiar for all parvoviruses in that they form hairpin struc tures, are not complementary, as they are for the second group (Section IV A). The second group, containing the so-called defective or satellite parvoviruses but also the autonomous densonucleosis viruses, do not need replicating cells.

The terminal hairpin structures play a crucial role in replication in that they provide a self-priming structure. The two different replicons (either lacking or possessing terminal repetition) give rise to two different reproduction mecha nisms. As a result, the first group encapsidates virtually only the " -" strand, whereas the second group encapsidates both strands separately. The molecular biology of the replication is not yet fully understood, but all observations still fit the Cavalier-Smith model (Cavalier-Smith, 1974) .

The replication of some parvoviruses has been characterized at the ultrastruc tural level. The first ultrastructural changes are generally observed 6-12 hours postinfection (PI) (Singer and Toolan, 1975; Garzon and Kurstak, 1976) . Garzon and Kurstak (1976) observed in the cytoplasm (1) a regression of the endoplasmic reticulum and the appearance of a large number of dispersed ribosomes; (2) a swelling and degeneration of organelles, such as the lysosomes and the mito chondria; and (3) a gradual development of paracrystalline arrays of small, round particles (17-20 nm) in vesicles. Bates et al. (1974) , who studied the morpho genesis in BPV, also found small particles in association with the smooth endoplasmic reticulum and suggested that they were virions. Their results differ from studies on the cytopathological effects of H-l virus on parasynchronous cell cultures (Singer and Toolan, 1974) , in which no virions could be detected in the cytoplasm before the onset of cell degeneration.
body_text.section: Ultrastructural Changes Related to Viral Development

body_text.text: Simultaneously, after a hypertrophy the nucleolus segregated into the pars fibrosa and the pars granulosa. Subsequently, a virogenic stroma appears in the nucleus in close relation to the nucleolus (Garson and . The development of this stroma is accompanied by a gradual disappearance of the granular portion of the nucleolus. The assembly of DNV seems to take place in islets in the virogenic stroma (Garzon and Kurstak, 1976) . Singer and Toolan (1975) found that mature H-l virions are mainly found on extranucleolar chromatin fibers, but, strikingly, not within the condensed chromatin. However, there seems to be an accumulation of apparently amorphous, unassembled viral protein in the condensed chromatin area.
body_text.section: Ultrastructural Changes Related to Viral Development

body_text.text: The studies by Singer and Toolan (1975) also showed that mature particles form extensive paracrystalline arrays on extracellular surfaces or on disrupted membranes. Interestingly, these paracrystals consist of either complete particles exclusively or almost entirely of incomplete particles. This suggests that the surface of the virion undergoes an alteration during the maturation. One might speculate that only particles which did not yet encapsidate DNA would be able to recognize it.
body_text.section: Ultrastructural Changes Related to Viral Development

body_text.text: An outstanding feature of parvovirus reproduction is its conjunction with nucleolar alterations. The nucleolus undergoes hypertrophy and segregation of its fibrillar and granular components (Garzon and Kurstak, 1976) . A similar nucleolar segregation can be caused by a variety of chemicals which interefere with nucleolar RNA synthesis (Simard et al., 1974) . Herpes and adenoviruses are also known to be able to induce segregation of the nucleolus (Sirtori and Bosisio-Bestetti, 1967; Matsui and Bernhard, 1967; Philips and Raskas, 1972) . A low level of a-amanitin, which also causes nucleolus segregation, inhibits AAV RNA synthesis (Bloom and Rose, 1978; Jay et al., 1978) . This is consis tent with the involvement of cellular RNA polymerase II with parvovirus tran scription. Though the nucleolus appears to have an affinity for the parvoviral proteins (Singer and Toolan, 1975) , actinomycin D, which prevents nucleolar function, does not inhibit the formation of the H-l hemagglutination factor (Rhode, 1973) .
body_text.section: The Nucleolus and Parvo virus Replication

body_text.text: The autonomous viruses (such as H-l, KRV, and BPV) require late S-phase events in the cell cycle for their replication (Tennant and Hand, 1970; Rhode, 1973) . Studies on the temporal relationship between AAV and helper virus seem to suggest that late adenovirus translation may be required for AAV replication (Rose, 1974) . Jay et al. (1978) provided evidence that the helper function acts on the precursor mRNA. The complete growth cycle of the parvoviruses takes about 20-24 hours (Cole and Nathanson, 1969; Rhode, 1973; . Cole and Nathanson observed by immunofluorescence that KRV antigens are synthesized in the cytoplasm of susceptible cells after a latent period of about 6 hours. Three hours later, these antigens appear in the nucleus, and about 20 hours PI infectious particles appear in the supernatant fluid. The time course of other parvoviruses is comparable to that of KRV, e.g., H-l (Rhode, 1973) , MVM (Tattersall, 1972; Dobson and Helleiner, 1973) , PPV (Bachmann, 1972) , FPV (Johnson, 1967a,b) , and AAV (Handaétf al., 1976; Rose, 1974) . The AAV proteins can first be detected about 4 hours after replication and transcription, which occur simultaneously about 4 hours after infection .

Subsequently, these proteins are transported to the nucleus and assembled into provirions. It is probable that packaging of the progeny viral DNA occurs after recognition of the terminal sequences of the genome by the provirion. This would explain why the so-called autonomous viruses package only the minus strand (the strand complementary to the mRNA), and the viruses of the second group (which possess terminal repetitions in their genomes) would package both the plus and the minus strands.

Most of the virus seems to be adsorbed to the cells within 2 hours (Rose and Koczot, 1972) , independently of a helper infection. A large fraction of the adsorbed virus penetrates into the cell. Berns and Adler (cited in observed that the viral DNA becomes sensitive to DNase only when it enters the nucleus. The uncoating seems, therefore, to occur during the penetration of or within the nucleus.
body_text.section: Penetration of the Virus into the Cell

body_text.text: As we have discussed in Section IV A, AAV DNA contains both inverted and natural terminal nucleotide sequence repetitions which account for about 1-3% of the total genome (145 nucleotides per extremity). showed that this palindromic sequence exists as a Y-shaped hairpin structure in which nucleotides 1-41 can pair with nucleotides 125-85. The nucleotides between 41 and 85 are found as two mutually inverted orientations, i.e., nucleotides a, b, c, . . . are in one case found from 42 up and in the other case from 84 down. Thus, the complete terminal sequence then exist as A-B-C-D-B*-A* (where A, B, C, or D represents nucleotide sequences and A* a nucleotide sequence complementary to A) and A-B-D*-C*-B*-A* and their respective com plementary sequences (the flip-flop model; .

Studies on the nucleotide sequences of the viral genome termini of four auton omous rodent parvoviruses (Astell et al., 1979) revealed that these viruses have also a Y-or T-shaped terminal structure, though somewhat shorter than for AAV (115-116 nucleotides). There is no evidence for the existence of a flip-flop structure in these viruses. Though only one of the two complementary strands is encapsidated and thus a single sequence orientation could be selected, prelimi nary results of Chow and Ward (cited in Astell et al., 1979) , using duplex RF DNA from infected cells, indicate only one sequence orientation.

The replication origin is located at the 3' end (Hauswirth and Berns, 1977; Singer and Rhode, 1977) and proceeds, using the hairpin as primer, unidirectionally. This is followed by site-specific nicking at the origin of the template so that the palindromic parental 3° terminal sequence is transferred and inversely linked to the progeny strand. The parental strand can serve as a primer and the progeny as the template for the resynthesis of the parental terminal nucleotide sequence. This model is analogous to the model proposed by Cavalier-Smith for linear chromosomal DNA replication, except that for parvoviruses no RNA primer synthesis is needed. An interesting and extensive review of the molecular biology of parvovirus (especially AAV) replication has been published by .

Early studies indicated that parvoviruses transcribed about 70% of their ge nomes and that this mRNA sedimented as a single component at about 18 S (Rose, 1974; Salzman and Redler, 1974) . Recent attempts to elucidate the tran scription process in parvoviruses revealed a more complicated mechanism. Tal et al. (1979) found that, after polyadenylation, about 30% of the RNA of the primary transcript of the MVM genome is spliced out. The poly(A) nuclear MVM RNA annealed to virtually the entire length of the viral genome. At one end of the genome a Y-shaped structure is obtained. One of the two arms of this structure is a duplex and the other is a single-stranded end. This could correspond to the hairpin duplex of the genome and the poly(A) 3' terminus of the RNA. At the other end of the duplex, there is a single-stranded region of varying length (up to 150 bases), and Tal et al. (1979) concluded that the transcription starts within the 3' end of the viral chromosome. These authors demonstrated that the cytoplasmic RNA is about 30% shorter than the nuclear RNA. They showed that the nuclear RNA consists of three parts: (1) the leader (about 9%); (2) the intervening sequences (about 30%), which are spliced out (the intron); and (3) the body (about 61%), which is thought to code for the viral protein(s). Their studies did not indicate whether more viral RNAs are present. However, studies with H-l (Green et al., 1979) indicated evidence for a single transcriptional unit and multiple-spliced polyadenylated transcripts.

The transcription seems to be slightly different for the AAVs (Jay et al., 1979; Laughlin et al., 1979) . The AAV DNA minus strand is also transcribed for about 90% (between 5 and 96 map units; 1 map unit equals 1% of the genome length). However, in addition to this RNA species, at least three other RNA species are found. The 5' terminus starts at 13, 19, or 39, whereas the 3' terminus and poly(A) sequences are always located at the 96 position (Laughlin et al., 1979) . They also demonstrated that most of the RNA is spliced between positions 40 and 49. These various RNA species seem to be transcription products not from defective interfering (DI) particles but from complete length viral genomes.,

The stable AAV transcript contains a poly(A) stretch of about 200 nucleotides (Carter, 1976) at its 3' terminus and 5' terminal cap structure (Carter et al., as cited in Berns and Haus wirth, 1979) . In vitro transcripts of AAV seem to require RNA polymerase II (Bloom and Rose, 1978) , an observation expected from the morphogenesis of this virus (Section VI, B, 2). Patton et al. (1979) obtained results indicating that the BPV genome is also transcribed by cellular RNA polymerase II.

cite_spans.text: (Carter et al., as cited in Berns and Haus wirth, 1979)

body_text.text: It has been shown for three parvoviruses (a representative of each of the three genera of the parvoviruses) that the viral proteins have common sequences (Sec tion IV B) (Tattersall et al., 1977; Lübeck et al., 1979; Tijssen and Kurstak, 1979b) . It is not yet clear if these proteins arise from posttranslational proteolytic cleavages, by processing at the nascent polypeptide level, or by the translation of different cytoplasmic mRNAs (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1981) . The importance of different proteins with similar sequence homologies is not clear, though it has been shown that maturation of these proteins may influence the infectivity of MVM (see Tattersall et al., 1977) . The assembly of the virion involves only secondary linkages among the constituent proteins, similar to the interaction of an antibody with its antigen (Tijssen and Kurstak, 1981) . These provirions encapsidate the single-stranded DNA in an as yet unknown way. Almost no free single-stranded viral DNA can be detected during infection (Rhode, 1974; Mayor and Jordan, 1976; Siegl and Gautschi, 1976) . This suggests that the provirion separates the two strands while encapsidating one of them. This model is sup ported by the finding (Rhode, 1976 ) that a mutant of H-l virus, which is temper ature sensitive due to an unstable capsid at higher temperatures, replicates DNA but does not produce progeny DNA at the nonpermissive temperature. Tattersall et al. (1977) demonstrated that the MVM virus becomes infectious only after the cleavage of B protein into C protein (molecular weight:61,000) while releasing a small peptide of about 3000 daltons. The A protein (molecular weight: 83,000), which contains the complete B sequence, is not cleaved, sug gesting that this cleavage site is buried inside the complete immature virion. It is also of interest that the sequence unique to A (about 180 amino acids) is rather basic (Tattersall et al., 1977) . This basic stretch might interact with the DNA in the full particles since no histones are incorporated . On the other hand, Kelly and Elliott (1977) showed that DNV DNA binds polyamines (organic polycations, namely putrescine, spermidine, and spermine) which may neutralize, at least partially, the negative charges of the DNA.
body_text.section: Protein Synthesis, Assembly, and Virion Maturation

body_text.text: The affinity of the autonomous parvoviruses for dividing cells is of consider able significance for understanding the in vivo pathogenesis and for the develop ment of reproducible in vitro assay procedures for these viruses. This proclivity for dividing cells sometimes makes it difficult to tell if a certain virus was the etiological agent or only adventitiously associated with diseases such as tumors and spontaneous abortions. However, most parvoviruses have been isolated from tissues or from virus stocks without pertaining to any specific disease, i.e., they often behave as latent viruses.

Frequently, it is difficult to establish firmly the original (natural) host of a certain parvo virus. The host range can be revealed by the presence of naturally occurring antibodies, since those animals have been exposed to the correspond ing virus under natural conditions. In addition to healthy laboratory or wild animals, antibodies can also be found in germ-free animals. Toolan et al. (1960) , Ferm and Kilham (1964) , and Kilham and Margolis (1966b) observed that at least some of the parovivurses can be transmitted vertically (by transplacental infections). In addition to these natural hosts, parvoviruses may infect a range of experimental hosts, especially neonates. Early parvovirus isolates (RV, H-l, H-3) were able, when introduced into newborn hamsters, to produce a facial bone malformation. Therefore, these agents were named "hamster osteolytic viruses." As Toolan and Ellem (1979) pointed out, this unfortunate designation led to the belief that parvoviruses were isolated from hamsters when, in reality, no naturally occurring parvovirus has been obtained from these animals. Another case of the controversy on the origin of parvoviruses is demonstrated by the H-1, HB, and HT history. After inoculation of human tumors or other fast-growing tissues into neonate hamsters, these viruses could be isolated, whereas numerous blind passages of hamster tumors or embryos in newborn hamsters were negative (Toolan, 1961 (Toolan, , 1964 (Toolan, , 1968 . Therefore, Toolan considered some of the H vi ruses to be of human origin. On the other hand, Kilham and Margolis (1969) isolated H-l virus from rat tissues. In contrast to the low incidence of antibodies to H-l virus in humans, Kilham and Margolis (1969) detected H-l antibodies in about 80% of both wild and laboratory rats.

The host range of the various autonomous parvoviruses is given in Table IX . This table demonstrates that some parvoviruses have a wider range of potential hosts than would be expected of viruses with limited genetic information (and therefore are more cell dependent).

In contrast to the autonomous viruses, AAV replication is independent of host cell replication but is determined by the stages of helper virus replication. Among the AAV serotypes, none could be related to a disease. It has even been shown that AAV may suppress the replication of their adenovirus helpers or other viruses and, therefore, may mediate among others a reduction in the number of adenovirus-caused tumors. An interesting example is provided by Pronovost et al. (1978) . They observed that the avian AAV reduced the pathogenicity of an adenovirus infection in vivo. Groups of chickens were infected with Tipton virus alone or in combination with high or low doses of avian AAV. In both trials they found that the associated virus delayed and reduced chick mortality. This effect was dose dependent and significant at the higher dose level. This table summarizes c References: RV, etc.: Kilham (1961) ; Toolan (1961) ; Kilham and Ferm (1964) ; Toolan (1966); ElDadah et al. (1967) ; Nicholson and Hetrick (1969); . H-1, etc.: Toolan (1966 Toolan ( , 1968 ; Kilham and Margolis (1969); Newman et al. (1970) . MVM: Kilham and Margolis (1970) . FVP/MEV: Urbain (1933) ; Kikuth et al. (1940) ; Syverton et al. (1943) ; Schofield (1949) ; Johnson et al. (1967) ; Kilham et al. (1967) . PPV: Cartwright and Huck (1967) ; Mayr et al. (1968) ; Cartwright et al. (1969); Bachman et al. (1975) . BPV: Abinanti and Warfield (1961) ; Inaba et al. (1973) ; Storz and Bates (1973) .

At present, MVM is the only parvovirus recovered from mice. Parker et al. (1970) found that about 80% of wild and laboratory mice contained HI antibodies to the virus. Infective MVM and specific antisera could be obtained from the blood of the same animals. Virus could also be recovered from the kidneys. The MVM infections are clinically inapparent.

The rat is the natural host of RT and a group of serologically related viruses (RV, HER, LS, XI4, H-3). Serological surveys demonstrated a wide distribution of these agents in laboratory and wild rat populations Moore and Nicastri, 1965; Robey et al., 1968) . Like MVM, these agents cause asymptomatic infections, and persistent virus and antibody may coexist in the same animal.

No parvoviruses have as yet been isolated from hamsters or guinea pigs, though the rat viruses mentioned above were once proposed to be of hamster origin (Nicholson and Hetrick, 1969) . Matsunaga et al. (1977) isolated and characterized a virus (RPV) from rabbit stool. This rabbit was experimentally infected with herpesvirus cuniculi and was free of anti-RPV antibodies prior to the inoculation; three other rabbits inoculated with this herpesvirus remained RPV free, so this virus probably was not a mere contaminant of this herpesvirus stock. The herpesvirus also might have activated a preexisting parvovirus infection. These investigators observed that among 90 "normal" rabbits, about 50% had an HI antibody titer of 16 or more to their isolate. Further experiments are needed to clarify this issue. Binn et al. (1970) isolated a parvovirus from the feces of dogs showing no signs of a clinically apparent infection. This MVC was serologically not related to other parvoviruses, and HI antibodies to this virus could be detected in a large part of the dog populations.

Another parvovirus (CEV) was isolated from fecal specimens from dogs with an epidemic gastroenteritis (Gagnon and Povey, 1979) . This agent showed crossreactivity with FPV by serological techniques and could be isolated in feline tissue cultures. However, its hemagglutination spectrum (Table VIII) seems to differ from that of FPV. Its biological similarity with FPV/MEV was further accentuated by the findings of Black et al. (1979) . They described the clinical manifestations of parvoviral enteritis and panleukopenia in 2-week to 1-year-old dogs. The histopathology of CEV is extremely similar to that of FPV/MEV. The morbidity is high and the mortality approaches 50%. Their isolate can also be propagated in feline cells but fails to grow in canine cells. In contrast to Gagnon and Povey (1979) , Black et al. (1979) discerned a serological cross-reactivity between CEV and PPV. McMaster et al. (1981) , however, found by restriction site mapping that of 79 mapped sites 86% were found to be common to the DNA of CEV and FPV/MEV.

The Felidae, such as cats, leopards, tigers, lions, and panthers, all seem to be susceptible to FPV, and the disease(s) induced have been named "feline panleukopenia," "feline ataxia," "feline aleukocytosis," "feline agranulocytosis," and "feline enteritis." The disease may be fatal or the recovery slow, sometimes associated with chronic diseases. In contrast to the most parvoviruses, FPV is also pathogenic for adult animals. Frequently it causes fatal acute enteritis with severe leukopenia in adults, whereas the same virus may produce cerebellar hypoplasia with ataxia and death in the fetus. MEV is probably the same agent as FPV, though clinicopathological features differ.

PPV is widespread in pig populations. Cartwright and Huck (1967) and Mengeling (1972) found one-third of pigs examined in England, Scotland, and the United States to possess antibodies to PPV. They also recovered PPV from about 90% of pigs from herds with reproductive failures. However, most isolates were ob tained from pigs with clinically inapparent infections (Mayr et al., 1968; Bach mann, 1969; Cartwright et al., 1969) . Early experiments with infection of antibody-free pregnant gilts or piglets by PPV resulted only in a viremia and mild leukopenia (Mayr et al., 1968; Johnson and Collings, 1969; Cartwright et al., 1971) . Nevertheless, recent reports associate PPV with mummification and fetal deaths in pigs and confirm the interesting results reported by Bachmann et al. (1975) on experimental in utero infections. Mengeling (1978) examined slaugh tered sows, which had been gravid for over 60 days, for dead fetuses and embryos. Dead fetuses were found in one-third of the litters (203), of which 75% contained PPV. The fetuses of the PPV-infected litters were mostly mummified (84%). Virtually all contained the viral antigen, whereas only half of the live litters possessed this antigen. Similar observations on outbreaks of mummifica tion and abortion in commercial piggeries were made in Australia (Gillick, 1977; Forman et al., 1977) . Experimental porcine parvovirus infections of fetal pigs resulted in abortion, histological changes, and antibody formation (Hogg et al., 1977) . Intrauterine inoculations at later stages of gestation appear to increase the chance of survival of the fetuses (Lenghaus et al., 1978) . This seems to be directly related to the increased number of mononuclear cells then present in many tissues (Lenghaus et al., 1978) . Though these results demonstrated that the pig is the natural host for PPV, it may also be the host of a number of other parvovirus isolates, such as the PPV-related KBSH virus. Studies by Croghan et al. (1973) suggested that viruses related to PPV may have been transmitted to the cultures by the use of trypsin (of porcine origin). Many of the 38 isolates obtained from permanent cell lines (Hallauer et al., 1971) appear closely related to PPV.

Like most parvoviruses, DDV is particularly pathogenic for neonates, espe cially 1-to 4-week-old goslings. The disease has been given various names: "goose plague," "goose influenza," "hepatonephritis," "infectious myocardi tis," "infectious enteritis," and "goose hepatitis." The name of "Derzsy's dis ease" was proposed after the author of the first description of this syndrome.

The parvovirus responsible for the above-mentioned diseases is therefore named "Derzsy's disease virus (DDV)." This virus has been demonstrated to be geo graphically widespread and also seems to be able to infect some ducklings (e.g., Cairina moschetta), whereas the common duck is resistant (Hoekstra et al., 1973) .

Experimental hosts have a distinctive advantage over natural hosts in that most natural hosts are immune and carry the virus in a latent form, so that experiments with those natural hosts are often unreliable.

Baby hamsters can be used as experimental hosts for several parvoviruses (if inoculated within 24-48 hours of birth), i.e. (1), MVM, (2) the RV and serologically related viruses, (3) the H-l, HB, and HT viruses, and (4) the Lu III and RT viruses. It is often necessary to make several passages through hamster neonates before the virus is adapted. The onset of the disease is mostly within a few days and is terminated fatally after about a week. Inoculation of adult hamsters, in general, gives only rise to the development of viral antibodies, though Toolan (1965) observed a cyclic viremia after incoulation with H-l virus. Later, Henry and Diario (1975) found H-l to cause hepatitis in adult animals. Sucklings inoculated at 5 days of age often develop a mongoloid-like deformity (Section VIII). The hamster does not apear to be susceptible to the FPV/MEV agent (Kikuth er 0/., 1940) or to PPV/KBSH (Hailauer ^Ö / . , 1972) .

Early attempts to inoculate baby mice experimentally with rat viruses failed, probably due to the low concentration of the agents. ElDadah et al. (1967) demonstrated that baby mice are susceptible to HER virus if the inoculum is concentrated. This was confirmed by Matsuo and Spencer (1969) by inoculation of BALB/c mice with concentrated RV suspensions. Mice are not susceptible to PPV or FPV/MEV (Urbain, 1933; Syverton et al., 1943) .
Rats, guinea pigs, and dogs have not yet been shown to be sensitive to a foreign parvovirus.
Among the RV, H-l, H-3, FPV/MEV, and HB viruses, only H-l could be shown to be pathogenic for rhesus monkeys (Kikuth et al., 1940; Toolan, 1966) .
DDV can be adapted to grow in embryonated eggs of the goose (Derzsy et al., 1970) and the duck (Cairina moschata; Hoekstra et al., 1973) , but not of the hen (Derzsy e/ al., 1970) .

In vitro cultivation of parvoviruses is frequently preferred over animal cultiva tion for the study of their replication processes. The undesired presence of prevalent latent parvoviruses requires special attention. The use of corresponding antisera appears to be practical and effective for eliminating the virus from contaminated cell lines (Mengeling, 1978) .
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: The host cell range of most nondefective parvoviruses is rather restricted, in contrast to most AAVs. Nearly all autonomous parvoviruses grow in cells de rived from their natural or experimental hosts (Table X) . A possible exception to this rule might be CEV (Black et al., 1979) . Its isolate failed to grow in canine cell cultures but could be propagated in feline cells. Eugster and Nairn (1977) had previously reported that this virus caused a minimal CPE in MDCK (dog) cells in the first passage but not in subsequent passages, whereas Gagnon and Povey (1979) confirmed the replication of this virus in feline tissue cultures.
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: In addition to cell lines derived from natural or experimental hosts, many different human and chimpanzee cell lines seem to support replication of certain parvoviruses (H-1, H-3, PPV, KBSH), whereas none of them is susceptible to other, sometimes closely related, parvoviruses (e.g., H-3 vs. RV; Table X ).
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: The autonomous parvovirus replication can often be stimulated by co-infection with an adenovirus. In cells supporting a parvovirus production (Kirk virus, XI4), adenovirus co-infection increased the hemagglutination titers of these viruses up to a hundredfold (Mirkovic et al., 1971) . Ledinko and Toolan (1968) observed that H-1 virus, which would not grow in secondary human embryonic lung cells, multiplied in these cells when an adenovirus was present as a helper.
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: Sera used to supplement growth media frequently (90%) have been shown to contain nonspecific inhibitors (Johnson, 1967b; Siegl and Kronauer, 1980) inter fering with the replication of the virus.
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: Reproduction of AAV depends not only on the host cell but also on the helper virus or on the host cell-helper virus combination. As a general rule, AAVs can and will replicate only in cells where adenovirus replicates, though the replica tion of adenovirus need not be complete to provide for the helping factors required by the AAVs.
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: Some AAV serotypes (types 1, 2, 3) seem to be able to replicate in almost any cell line which can also produce adenovirus (Casto et al., 1967) .
