For instance, AAV-1 was able to grow in, among others, chicken embryo cultures, Vero cells, African green monkey kidney cells, human embryonic kidney cells, BSC-1, calf kidney cells, swine kidney cells, HeLa, HEp-2, KB, dog kidney cells, mouse kidney cells, and hampster kidney cells with different helpers, such as ICH (infectious canine hepatitis), SA7 (simian adenovirus type 7), SVI5 (simian virus type 15), and CELO (chick embryo lethal orphan virus) (Casto et al., 1967; Boucher et al., 1969; Ishibashi and Ito, 1971) . Others, such as AAV-4, appear to be restricted and will grow in a very limited number of cell lines. AAV-4 seems to require African green monkey kidney cells, whereas in other cells fluorescent antibody (FA)-stainable antigen and CF antigen, but no infectious virus, could be produced.
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: Adenovirus 12 was reported to be 5-to 25-fold more efficient in inducing 4^ 4^
body_text.section: D. Cell Lines Supporting Parvovirus Replication

body_text.text: FA-stainable AAV antigen in FL cells than other adenoviruses studied (Smith and Thiel, 1967) . Studies on the temporal relationships between AAV and its helper show that relatively late events in the adenovirus replication are needed for AAV production (Hoggan, 1970; Rose, 1974) . Cells which express only early events in the adenovirus cycle, such as T-antigen synthesis, do not support AAV replication Rose, 1974) .

AAV exhibits, under certain conditions, an interference with the adenovirus replication. This interference is not mediated with an interferon (-like soluble substance) (Parks et al., 1968) but depends directly on the concentration of the AAV inoculum (Casto et al., 1967) . If the adenovirus infection is allowed to progress for about 10 hours before infection with AAV, then its replication is no longer sensitive to AAV interference (Parks et al., 1968) .

AAV may also interfere with itself. Infection of KB cells with AAV multiplici ties of 10-20 TCID50 per cell (Ad2 as helper) provides the highest AAV yields (IO 4 TCID50 per cell), whereas a tenfold increase of the AAV multiplicity results in only IO 3 TCID50 or less per cell (Rose and Koczot, 1972; Rose, 1974) . Mixed infections with two AAV serotypes often result in a strong domination of one of the two serotypes (Torikai and Mayor, 1969; Hoggan, 1971 ).

The development of plaque formation assays greatly facilitated the quantita tion analysis and allows plaque purification of virus strains. These tests are especially helpful for the study of parvoviruses, since titration by quantitation of either the intranuclear inclusion bodies (which are often transient for parvoviruses ; Flagstad, 1975) in hematoxylin-eosin-stained coverslip cultures or the cells positive in the immunofluorescence tests is usually imprecise, cumbersome, and not sensitive. Plaque assays have been described for several parvoviruses: FPV/MEV (Siegl and Kronauer, 1980) , MVM (Tattersall, 1972) , RV (Brailovsky, 1966) , H-l (Ledinko, 1967) , and BPV (Storz and Bates, 1973) .
body_text.section: E. Plaque Formation of Parvoviruses in Tissue Cultures

body_text.text: Due to the dependence of the parvoviruses on actively dividing cells, cultural conditions, such as viability and number of cells as well as the time interval between seeding of the cells and their inoculation, must be strictly controlled in order to obtain monolayers with a maximal number of mitotically active cells. The virus is allowed to adsorb to the cells for 1 to 2 hours. Subsequently, the cells are covered with an overlay medium. The monolayers are stained with neutral red 5 days PI and the plaques counted 1 day later. Plaque morphology has not yet been shown to be a characteristic useful for the differentiation of virus strains.
body_text.section: E. Plaque Formation of Parvoviruses in Tissue Cultures

body_text.text: Parvoviruses have, in general, a tendency to adhere to membrane fragments (see Toolan and Ellem, 1979) (Fig. 4) . The purification of virus from minced organs (especially kidneys) of infected animals or cell cultures relies on the findings that these viruses dissociate from cellular material at high pH, at low ionic strength, and in the presence of EDTA . A rapid isolation procedure is often essential, since extensive proteolysis is known to occur during parvovirus purification. After homogenization or lysis of infected cells with trypsin and deoxycholate (Berns and Rose, 1970) , pelleting of the cellular debris and, if necessary, lipid extraction, two different approaches are possible for further purification and concetration of the virus: (1) differential centrifugation or, if possible, (2) precipitation of the virus, e.g., with 25 mM CaCb . These steps are followed by sedimenta tion on a sucrose gradient and (or directly) on an isopycnic CsCl density gradi ent. On CsCl gradients, several bands of virus may be obtained which are often not resolved in the sucrose step (see Section IV D).

The propensity of parvoviruses to damage mitotic cells led to the expression "mitolytic viruses" (O'Shea and Studdert, 1978) . This mitolytic action explains the pathogenicity of these viruses. Though many of these viruses are normally latent, clinical cases may arise after the infection of rapidly growing tissues. Parvoviruses may sometimes pass the placenta in pregnant animals, often with serious consequences for the fetus (e.g., abortion, stillbirth, malformation). Infection of newborn animals will affect particularly the fast-growing tissues (leading to, e.g., ataxia). The pathogenicity of older or adult animals is usually related to infection of constantly proliferating tissues, such as lymphopoietic and erythropoietic organs and intestines. Healing of infected regenerating tissues may be significantly delayed.
body_text.section: VIII. CLINICAL AND PATHOLOGICAL FEATURES AND DIAGNOSIS

body_text.text: The dependence of different syndromes of diseases caused by the same virus on age of the animal, other infective agents, and mode of infection is clearly illustrated by the FPV/MEV infections. Whereas Kilham et al. (1967) showed FPV/MEV to infect the external germinal layer of the cerebellum followed by severe ataxia, Hindle and Findlay (1932) concluded that FPV had no neurotropism, because these authors were able to reproduce only the classical panleukopenia by intracerebral inoculation of cats. Originally, these two syndromes were, therefore, thought to be caused by two different viruses-feline ataxia virus (FAV), isolated by Kilham and Margolis (1966a) , and FPV, isolated by Verge and Christoferoni (1928)-but Johnson et al. (1967) showed that these viruses are identical agents. The two parameters, age of the animal and mode of infection, determine the syndrome of the infected host.
body_text.section: A. Infections of Fedilae, Mustelida, and Procyonidae

body_text.text: After an infection, the number of white blood cells may be abnormally de creased, leading to a condition called "leukopenia." The number of granulocytes may be reduced as a result of an obstruction by the virus of the producing centers in the marrow. Though a mild deficiency may be harmless, in an acute form the disease, characterized by a severe shortage of granulocytes (agranulocytosis), can be detrimental. As a result, other infections are liable to develop which, as we will see later, are of the utmost importance for the severity of the disease.

Animals having these syndromes were at least 1-week-old when infected. The incubation period is about 3 days Syverton et al., 1943; Lucas and Riser, 1945; Ichijo et al., 1976) . Fever and listlessness, accompanied by a gradual decline in white blood cell counts, are followed by vomiting, loss of appetite (anorexia), dehydration, and depression, and sometimes by diarrhea or other side effects, depending on simultaneous infections by other agents. Ichijo et al. (1976) reported clinical and hematological findings and myelograms ob tained from natural and experimental cases of feline panleukopenia. The initial clinical symptoms in experimental cases were detected the third day after inocu lation. The characteristic hematological changes in the peripheral blood included neutrocytopenia, eosinocytopenia, and monocytopenia. Ichijo et al. (1976) also observed in all (experimental and natural) cases a drastic decrease in nucleated cells, in particular immature cells of the myeloid and erythroid series in the aspirated bone marrow. In animals with advanced leukopenia, the white blood cell counts drop until the fifth day, when less than 1000 cells/mm 3 were observed for fatal cases. Schultz et al. (1976) demonstrated that FPV has its primary immunosuppressive effect on T-cell activity, but that this effect is not so severe as for feline leukemia viruses in kittens or canine distemper virus in dogs. Inoculation of germ-free and specific-pathogen-free cats resulted in anorexia and a slight diarrhea (Carlson et al., 1977) . Both the germ-free and the specific-pathogenfree cats had thymic involution. None of the cats died in these experiments of Carlson et al. It is of interest to note that Bittle et al. (1961) were able to induce the classical syndrome including vomiting, pyrexia, dehydration, and diarrhea only by dual infection of the cats by FPV and a myxovirus. Hammon and Enders (1939) reported, in addition to leukopenia, the occur rence of mild anemia. Syverton et al. (1943) and Lawrence et al. (1943) described the malady in detail: extreme granulocytopenia; less pronounced leu kopenia; hypoplasia with absence of differentiation of the myeloid cells of the bone marrow; proliferation of reticuloendothelial cells of lymph nodes and spleen; and intranuclear inclusion bodies in the cells of the gastrointestinal mucosa, lymph nodes, and bronchial mucosa. The liver, pancreas, and kidney respond late to the disease (Lucas and Riser, 1945) and, in parallel with the viral replication in the lymphoid and blood-forming tissues, the mucosa of the small intestine is slightly damaged in the terminal portion before the process extends to the duodenum. In both there is an extreme destruction of villi and epithelium of the crypts of Lieberkühn. The fine structure of the epithelial cells of Lieberkühn's crypts during infection has been studied in detail by electron microscopy (Okaniwa et al., 1977) . The most important changes associated with the replication of FPV in the nucleus were alterations in the lining epithelial cells of the crypts.

In fatal cases, death usually occurs about 3 days after the onset of the disease. A complete recovery of the animals may take from a few days to several weeks; however, they may suffer from chronic diarrhea. FPV must also be considered as a possible cause of fertility problems.

Feline ataxia was considered, since its first description in 1888, to be of toxic or genetic origin (Herringham and Andrewes, 1888) . Jones et al. (1964) , howev er, failed to show a genetic reason for ataxia even though a chromosome trisomy was found in affected cats. Kilham and Margolis (1966a) succeeded in isolating the feline ataxia virus (FAV) agent which caused the disease in the offspring of inoculated (or parentally given) virus-free pregnant queens. The virus passes through the placental barrier and attacks the external germinal layer of the cere bellum, followed by an early inclusion body phase and cytopathic effects, re spectively, which lead to a severe degree of cerebellar hypoplasia. Cats with "spontaneous" ataxia showed the same pathological features.

The disease is recognizable within a few weeks postnatally. The time needed to cause a severe hypoplasia suggests a primary virus replication cycle in the maternal tissues. Newborn kittens are susceptible to ataxia until they are about 1-week-old, after which the availability of the mitotic cells in the external germi nal layer of the cerebellum decreases drastically. Kilham et al. (1967) noted similarities between infection by this virus and fatal infections by rubella or cytomegalovirus (CMV) in man. They were able to isolate the virus from the cerebellum, kidneys, ileum, and mesenteric lymph nodes.

As mentioned earlier, Johnson et al. (1967) showed the FPV/MEV virus to be identical to FAV. The differences in the syndromes show that the expression of the disease depends on the development of the animal.

The most common expression of an FPV/MEV infection in mink is a severe enteritis (Schofield, 1949; Wills, 1952) . About 5 days after the infection, stools become watery and contain mucus. The hemorrhagic content of the intestines and the casts is caused by a marked necrosis and desquamation of the columnar epithelium of the intestinal mucosa. A serious effect of this disease is the loss of water and salt. Especially in kits, high mortality may occur (up to 80%). Peracute infections without diarrhea, but in which anorexia is soon followed by death, are rare (Knox, 1960) . Sometimes vomiting occurs. Normal feces reap pear about 6 days after the onset of the disease.

Many of the infected minks develop leukopenia (McPherson, 1956; Myers et al., 1959; Reynolds, 1969) . Hemorrhages just beneath the capsule of the spleen, congested mesenteric lymph nodes, and hemorrhagic catarrhal exudates in the intestines are revealed by necropsy of the affected animals. The crypts of Lieb erkühn show the same pathological features as affected felines.

A commercially desirable pigmentation is obtained in the pelt of minks with the Chediak-Higashi syndrome. The homozygous recessive gene in these Aleu tian minks also causes an increased susceptibility to Aleutian disease virus (ADV). This disease is characterized by anorexia and diarrhea followed by death. Trautwein et al. (1974) reported an immunodepression toward other antigens due to the vigorous antiviral response. This causes an increased susceptibility to other infections. ADV also severely affects the lymphoid system. The virema reaches a peak after a week (Porter et al., 1969) . Other minks are less susceptible (Larsen and Porter, 1975) . The virus may, however, be transmitted transplacentally {Gorhametal, 1976).

We have seen in Section VII, B, that the incidence of PPV infections in pig herds is very high and that this virus occurs worldwide. Initial studies on the pathogenicity of this virus were confusing since PPV could be isolated not only from stillborn, aborted, and mummified fetuses or from pigs with reproductive failures but also from apparently healthy piglets (Cartwright and Huck, 1967) . These results were confirmed by later studies (Section VII, B). Bachmann et al. (1975) studied the development of the fetuses infected in utero by direct inoculation in the amniotiç fluid. They demonstrated that PPV, like all parvoviruses, has an affinity for mitotic cells. This explains the high susceptibility of the young fetuses for this virus, whereas the infected sows do not show any clinical symptoms. Intrauterine infection of the fetuses at a younger age (35-, 48-, or 55-days-old) resulted in their death and mummification, whereas fetuses from sows infected at 72, 99, and 105 days of gestation survived. Their results confirmed studies by Cartwright et al. (1971) and Johnson and Collings (1971) , in which pregnant sows were orally or intravenously infected, that fe tuses infected at later stages did not result in abortions or stillbirths. This coin cides with the onset of immunological competence of the fetal pigs at 60-70 days of gestation (Done and Hebert, 1968; Jamrichova er al., 1971) . Intrauterine infections at later stages resulted in the development of a high antibody titer in utero (Bachmannetal., 1975) .

Many factors, such as immunocompetence, body temperature, gestational ages, period of infection, route of infection, and pathogenicity of the virus strains may all influence the outcome of the infection. This may also explain the con flicting results concerning the histopathology of infected fetuses reported by Nauta et al. (1975) , who recorded brain lesions, and Mengelingei al. (1975) and Cutlip and Mengeling (1975) , who failed to induce histological lesions. Transplacental crossing of PPV, similar to that of other parvoviruses such as FPV/MEV, was reported (Johnson and Collings, 1971 ). However, Bachmann et al. (1975) suggested that only very small quantities of virus pass the transplacental barrier. Body temperature of pigs, which is known to fluctuate considerably (average 39°C), may also have an influence on the replication of the virus, since the virus reproduces considerably better at lower temperatures (Bachmann, 1972) . Joo et al. (1977) demonstrated different patterns in histopathology and immu-nofluorescence in two groups of fetuses examined at about 62 and 95 days of gestation, respectively. Viral antigen could be detected by immunofluorescence only in fetuses which had not reached the stage of immuno-competence, i.e., 70 days of gestation (Joo et al., 1976a) . However, histopathological changes were constantly evident in older fetuses (Joo et al., 1977) . The immunofluorescence results of Joo et al. (1977) were in agreement with those obtained by Cutlip and Mengeling (1975) . Fluorescence was evident in the parenchyma of the lung, liver, and kidney and in the neurons and vascular endothelium of the cerebrum. Histopathological changes included perivascular lesions around veins and capil laries, often the brain (meningoencephalitis), and interstitial hepatitis and nephri tis. The degree of severity of cellular necrosis seems to depend on the gestational age (Hogg et al., 1977) . In older fetuses there is, in general, less cellular necrosis. Many histological changes seem to be caused by an immune response with cellular infiltrations; polymorphonuclear leukocytes were more prominent in lesions of the lung and placenta, and there were reactive changes in the lymphoid tissues. However, the etiology of the calcifications of the placenta (regardless of gestational age) is still uncertain.

BPV seems widely distributed in cattle herds, as most animals possess antibodies against this virus (Abinanti and Warfield, 1961; Spahn et al., 1966; Storz and Bates, 1973) . Johnson (1969) was unsuccessful in his attempts to isolate the virus from aborted calves or from calves with cerebral hypoplasia or with corticocerebral necrosis.

The initial nomination for this virus (HADEN-hemadsorbing enteric virus of calves) indicates that it may be associated with enteric diseases of calves. Bates et al. (1972) failed to find a significant number of parvovirus isolates from calves suffering from diarrhea. However, in a subsequent study, Storz and Bates (1973) , using experimental BPV infections of colostrum-deprived calves, demonstrated the development of diarrhea and a widespread viremia. In a recent review, Storz et al. (1978) discussed the pathogenesis of these intestinal infections and the role of various serum factors in the cultivation and isolation of BPV.

Several dog diseases have been linked to the parvovirus(es): enteritis, myocar ditis, and panleukopenia. The virus which is associated wth the epidemic gastro enteritis seems to be related to FPV/MEV (Section VII, B).
At postmortem, the most striking feature of the disease is a severe loss of intestinal epithelium in the crypts of the small intestine (Thomson and Gagnon,

1978). The bone marrow and lymphoid tissue in Peyer's patches, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus are also affected (Kelly, 1978; Coopera al., 1979) . These lesions are easily distinguished from those caused by coronavirus but are quite similar to the lesions found in animals affected by feline panleukopenia.

A sudden death of puppies in the 4-to 8-week age range may also result from primary nonsuppurative myocarditis (Hayes et al., 1979) . According to these authors, the most outstanding histopathological characteristics are pulmonary edema and intranuclear inclusion bodies in the cardiac myofibers. These intra nuclear inclusion bodies are characteristic of parvoviruses (Fig. 2 ). This descrip tion by Hayes et al. (1979) is similar to the myocarditis of probable viral origin, in pups of weaning age, described by Jezyk et al. (1979) . The latter also ob served cardiomegaly and cardiac arrhythmias in the surviving pups.

Different names have been used in different countries to describe goose infec tions by the same virus. In the Netherlands, van Cleef and Miltenburg (1966) spoke of "goose plague," whereas in Italy and Russia the disease was described as "infectious myocarditis" and "infectious enteritis," respectively (Kontrimavitchus, 1968; Mandelli et al., 1970) ; in Hungarian literature the disease was described as "goose influenza" (Csontos and Miklovich-Kia Csatari, 1967) , in Germany (Schettler, 1971a) as "goose hepatitis," and in France (Coudert et al., 1972) as "hepatonephritic syndrome." Süveges and Széensengi (1970) stated that massive losses among goslings (80-90%) were caused by inoculations with certain lots of reconvalescent serum administered as a protective measure against "goose influenza." Schettler (1971a) isolated the etiological agent, a virus, which multiplied in embryonated goose eggs. Schettler (1971c) showed the causative agent to be a parvovirus, which was confirmed by Dannacher et al. (1974) ; the latter also demonstrated that the virus replicates on Barbary duck cultures.

Young goslings less than 2 weeks of age are the most sensitive (Coudert et al., 1972) . After infection, they stop eating and show signs of hyperthermia ( 4 1 -41.7°C) and diarrhea. Besides, they may have nervous troubles and die, usually within 2 days (Coudert et al., 1972; Kontrimavitchus, 1974) .

Goslings infected when they were 2-to 4-weeks-old usually survive (about 75%), though they remain rather weak. The diseased goslings ruffle up their feathers and show symptoms of hyperthermia, isolation, often diarrhea, growth rate retardation, and locomotor problems, and lose most of their down. The onset of these symptoms is age dependent and decreases in severity, with a more protracted course and fewer deaths when goslings are infected at later stages (Schettler, 1971b) .

The pathological features of diseases caused by rodent parvoviruses are most prominent in experimental infections. It is not yet completely clear how much these symptoms are representative of the "natural diseases." Under natural con ditions, the coexistence of antibody and virus in a large part of the rodent population seems to prevent the development of a clinical syndrome. The follow ing observations are all made after experimental infections.

The HER strain, isolated by ElDadahei al. (1967) , attacks the nervous system of suckling rats. Nathanson et al. (1970) and Cole et al. (1970) noted a severe hemorrhage and necrosis in the brain and spinal cord, which resulted in a fatal paralysis.

The LS and RV strains, however, induce cerebellar ataxia in newborn ham sters (Lum and Schreiner, 1963; Kilham and Margolis, 1964) and in rats (Kilham and Margolis, 1966b) . The pathogenesis is similar to the one caused in kittens by FAV (Section VIII, A, 2). These virus strains adapt easily to the hamster, and after three passages they are able to cause a fatal hemorrhagic enteritis.

H-3 and H-l virus pathogenicity for newborn hamsters and rats is increased in a similar way (Kilham, 1961; Toolan, 1961; Moore and Nicastri, 1965) , result ing in the same syndrome (hemorrhagic enteritis) 7-14 days PI, and death occurs only a few hours later. Only a small percentage of the infected baby hamsters survive, but these survivors tend to develop mongolism (Fig. 5) (Toolan, 1960 (Toolan, , 1968 . In the case of mongolism, the mitolytic action of these parvoviruses results in a strong osteolytic activity (fragile bones, malformation of teeth caused by a degeneration of the odontoblasts and a cystic necrosis of the supporting stroma, microcephalic domed head resulting in protruding eyes). These symp toms can be observed after 2 weeks, and the affected hamsters remain dwarfish. The osteolytic activity is also evident in the delay that these agents cause in the healing of osseous wounds (Engler et al., 1966) . Detailed and comparative

studies on the osteolytic activity of these viruses on the developing teeth have been described by Baer and Kilham (1962a , b, 1964a and Cohen and Shklar (1964) . As expected, the severity of the clinical symptoms is strongly age dependent. An infection of hamsters which are older than 3 weeks does not cause osteolytic symptoms. However, H-1 virus is found to induce hepatitis in adult hamsters (Henry and Diario, 1975) .

Newborn hamsters infected with MVM sometimes show characteristics re sembling mongolism, but more often they have a sometimes fatal enteritis (Kilham and Margolis, 1970) . The same investigators found that rats are only subclinically infected. Under natural conditions, MVM seems not to infect hamsters but might infect rats (Parker et al., 1970) . Newborn mice experimentally infected with MVM seem to have only an initial retardation in the growth rate. No clinical ataxia is observed, though virus can be recovered from the brain (Kilham and Margolis, 1970) .

The outstanding features of the transmission of parvoviruses are (1) high resistance of virus to physical and chemical treatment, resulting in an extreme stability of the infectious entity; (2) coexistence of circulating antibodies and viruses; (3) frequent recovery of virus from the gut, blood, or milk, enabling the transmission, at least in principle, by the fecal-oral route, wounds and insects such as fleas, and by lactation; (4) transplacental crossings for some parvoviruses; and (5) cosmopolitan nature of most parvoviruses.

Apart from Europe, DDV has also been found in Israel, China, and Vietnam (Samberg et al., 1972; Hanh, 1974) . In Vietnam, the disease was widely spread by war-motivated movements of the population (Hanh, 1974) . The isolated virus is also similar to its European counterpart. Besides the domestic goose, the Canada goose (Branta canadensis), snowgoose (Anser coerulescens), and Barbary duck (Cairina moschata) may also be infected, but Hoekstra et al. (1973) failed to infect the Peking Barbary duck hybrids. The commonest infection by DDV occurs by the fecal-oral route.

FPV/MEV is also disseminated by feces, urine, and saliva Schofield, 1949; Reynolds, 1969) . The coexistence of antibodies and virus demonstrated that animals may remain a source of infection for several months after their recovery (Gorham and Hartsough, 1955; Johnson, 1969) . This virus is now widely distributed throughout the world, but natural infections, combined with vaccinatino, have provided an immunity sufficient to prevent such large epizootics as occurred about 50 years ago (Urbain, 1933) .
Throughout the world, bovine sera contain antibodies against BPV-1 (Abinanti and Warfield, 1961; Slovzetal, 1972; Storz and Bates, 1973; Wosu et al., 1979) .

In Japan, Inabaet al. (1973) isolated another BPV strain (BPV-2) distinguishable from BPV-1. Kudron and Mocsari (1979) observed, in a serological screening of large-scale pig herds in Hungary for PPV infections, that more than 75% of the samples were positive. Herds with reproductive failure were all positive. This virus has been reported to circulate in pig herds with similar frequency through out the world (see Section VII, B). PPV may be transmitted by the transplacental and the fecal-oral routes.

There is a high incidence of specific RV antibodies in rat sera (Robey et al., 1968) , indicating persistent latent infections. As we have seen with the MEV/FPV and PPV viruses, the viruses and their antibodies may coexist. Therefore, an apparently healthy immune animal may continue to be a reservoir for infecting virus.

Passive immunity was demonstrated to be important in preventing RV infec tions. Kilham and Moloney (1964) showed that suckling rats could be infected only when their mothers had no immunity to the virus. Suckling piglets also have a high incidence of high antibody titers (Bachmann, 1969) , but results of John son and Collings (1969) and Cartwright et al. (1971) suggest that this immunity might be actively acquired. More recent results by Hogg et al. (1977) indicated that the fetuses acquire immunity when the gilts are infected during gestation, but the virus also provokes histological lesions and abortions. Depending on the immunity of the queens, suckling kittens acquire a passive immunity (Johnson, 1965; Scott et al., 1970) . Kisary (1977) reported that laying geese naturally infected with DDV transmit IgG-type maternal immunoglobulins through the eggs to their offspring. These antibodies persisted until the third week of life (the half-life of these antibodies is about 6 days), confirming an earlier report by Kisary et al. (1975) . Kisary (1977) suggested, therefore, that the most efficient approach to protect goslings against DDV would be the active immunization of the laying flocks.
body_text.section: X. IMMUNITY, VACCINATION, PREVENTION, AND CONTROL

body_text.text: Active immunity has been best studied with the rodent viruses as antigens. Experimental infections usually result in a viremia about a week after the inocu lation (Toolan, 1965; Kilham and Margolis, 1969) . The first antibodies appear at about the same time, and the titer increases to a certain level and may then remain constant for a long time (Toolan, 1968) . This is readily explained by the existence of continuously produced virus. Instead, if weanling hamsters are infected with the osteolytic agents, the level drops after some time unless the animals are reinoculated. Therefore, virus production seems to be a prerequisite for the maintenance of high antibody titers. This model seems to be valid for the other parvoviruses as well: PPV: Bachmann (1969) ; MVM: Parker et al. (1970) ; FPV/MEV: Gorham and Hartsough (1955) ; . In the field,

passively acquired antibodies may, however, interfere with the development of an active immunity (Kisary, 1977) .Vaccination proved efficient in enhancing the active immunity. A live virus (FPV/MEV) vaccine attenuated on tissue culture has been developed (Gorham et al., 1965 (Gorham et al., , 1966 . Chappuis and Petermann (1979) recently discussed the prophy laxis of infectious panleukopenia in combination with other viruses (rhinotracheitis virus, herpesvirus, and calici virus). They presented an immunization program for these viruses with the different vaccines available. In the early control of DDV, goslings were protected by subcutaneous injections of convalescent serum (Coudert et al., 1973) . Kisary et al. (1978) attenuated the DDV agent according to the same principle as above for FPV/MEV. A serial transfer of the DDV agent in cultured goose embryo fibroblasts resulted in a mutant apathogenic for the goslings. Vaccinated geese had a considerably lower mortality, and the average weight of the animals was considerably higher.An inactivated virus vaccine was developed for the prevention of porcine parvo virus-induced reproductive failures (Mengeling et al., 1979) . In these ex periments, the virus was inactivated with acetylethyleneimine and the gilts were vaccinated intramuscularly before they were bred and were subsequently ex posed orally to virulent PPV on the ninetieth day of gestation. After 12 weeks of gestation, the gilts were killed and the litters examined for the presence of virus or antibodies. Neither could be detected in the fetuses of the vaccinated gilts, in contrast to the fetuses of the control gilts. Moreover, of the latter, 26 of the 37 fetuses were dead.It is also evident from Section IX that general hygienic measures will be of great importance for the effective control of parvoviruses. Newly acquired ani mals should be kept separate from others. As Balogh (1973) has demonstrated, this helps significantly to reduce the incidence of the disease. Also, disinfection and importation controls often may be important.
